Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Machine Learning, Theory and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The REU Site program involves participants in research projects in machine learning techniques and emerging applications, including text analytics and health informatics. Student projects are expected to yield results that will contribute to ubiquitous software-based technologies in innovative ways. The students are introduced to the research topics and helped to obtain in-depth understanding through introductory and on-going presentations. The REU Site program is focusing on training future computer scientists from institutions with limited research opportunities. An emphasis is given to recruiting under-represented minority students into computer science research at an early age. The research experience will encourage these students to be productive researchers in academic and non-academic environments during their future careers.

The REU students will be involved in research in machine learning and its applications in diverse and emergent areas such as intelligent software testing, intelligent complier design, health informatics and natural language processing. Students have the opportunity to utilize a combination of theoretical reading, analysis, and research within laboratory environments. The students develop algorithms to solve interesting and timely problems, develop software, perform hands-on research on novel problems, conduct experiments, and gain experience writing scientific papers and in oral presentation of their work in a conference-like setting. More information on this project can be found at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs REU Site website (http://www.cs.uccs.edu/~jkalita/reu.html).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU project was carried out  over three summers, 2014 through 2016. There were five professors involved: Drs. Terrance Boult, Jugal Kalita, Rory Lewis, Kristen Justice and Qing Yi. The overall theme was Machine Learning, and sub-themes were Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Medical Informatics, Software Engineering, and Compiler Optimization. Our students explored the use of machine learning in these disparate disciplines, conducted mentored research in cutting-edge problems and also published at a high rate. We received  30, 41 and 46 applicants in 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively.  22.2% were accepted and attended. 

During the period, we had one African-American female, two Hispanic males and one transgender woman. 20.7% of the students were female, and 27.5% were minorities or female. Our main strength is training students from from non-research schools with almost 80% of our students coming from such schools. 

We published 12 papers based on work done by the REU students from 2014-2016. The publication of these papers gave opportunity to the students to present them before a scholarly and disciplinary audience. It gave them a highly sought record before applying for admission into PhD programs or jobs.  In addition, some of the ideas and results presented in the papers were cutting-edge. We present three such exemplar works below.  These three efforts describe the use of machine learning in algorithm selection, intrusion detection and creation of word sense embeddings. 

Computational software programs, such as Maple and Mathematica, rely on superfunctions and meta-algorithms to select the optimal algorithm for a given task. These meta-algorithms may require intensive mathematical proof to formulate, incur large computational overhead, or fail to consistently select the best algorithm. The work performed by Matthew Simpson, mentored by Drs. Yi and Kalita, in the 2016 REU, showed that machine learning demonstrates a promising alternative for automatic algorithm selection by easing the design process and overhead while also attaining high accuracy in selection. This work was published in the IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning (ICMLA) in 2016. 

Most intrusion detection system evaluations have been performed in a closed set protocol in which only classes seen during training are considered during classification. Thus far, there has been no realistic application in which novel types of behaviors unseen at training – unknown classes as it were – must be recognized for manual categorization. A paper by Steve Cruz and Cora Coleman, who were both REU students in 2016, with Dr. Boult as the mentor and a co-author, evaluates malware classification using both closed set and open set protocols for intrusion recognition. In contrast to much of the previous work, they employ a fine-grained recognition protocol, in which the dataset is loosely open set – i.e., recognizing individual intrusion types – e.g., “sendmail”, “snmp guess”, ..., etc., rather than more general attack categories. Theye employed two different classifier types – Gaussian RBF kernel SVMs, which are not theoretically guaranteed to bound open space risk, and W-SVMs, which are theoretically guaranteed to bound open space risk. They found that the W-SVM offers superior performance under the open set regime, particularly as the cost of misclassifying unknown classes at query time  increases. This paper was published at a workshop at the CVPR (Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition) in 2017. 

Popular distributional approaches to semantics allow for only a single embedding of any particular word. A single embedding per word conflates the distinct meanings of the word and their appropriate contexts, irrespective of whether those usages are related or completely disjoint. David Foley, an REU student in 2016 working under the mentorship of Dr. Kalita,  compared models that use the graph structure of the knowledge base WordNet as a post-processing step to improve vector-space models with multiple sense embeddings for each word, and explore the application to word sense disambiguation. This paper was published in ICON (International Conference on Natural Language Processing).

We recently got in touch with the REU students to find out what they are doing. Fifteen of the 29 students replied to email or text message questions. Seven of our REU students are in PhD programs, all in Computer Science: Cora Coleman (2016), UC San Diego;  Steve Cruz (2015), UC Colorado Springs; David Foley (2016), Penn State;  Abigail Graese (2016), Notre Dame; Cody Kinner (2014), CMU; Liam Schramm (2016), Rutgers; Noah Weber (2015), Stonybrook. One has just graduated with her Bachelors: Andrea Costas (2016), Rice University, and is looking for a job. At least seven are working in industry: Miguel Aleman (2014), Goldman Sachs; Kamal Kamaladin (2016), Clinic Co.; Conor McGrory (2014), Google; Nathan Harmon (2016), MITRE; Alanya Kennedy (2016), IBM; Adam Barker (2016), Cosmic AES; Kyra Yee (2016), Facebook. Clinic is a start-up working on conversational AI with 70 employees, and Kamal heads their Quality Control division.
